[Notre Dame Magazine](https://magazine.nd.edu/), my alma mater’s quarterly alumni publication, runs an [annual contest](https://magazine.nd.edu/news/young-alumni-essay-contest-2017-rules/) for nonfiction, first person essays from young alumni. I’ve considered entering since the contest first began, but I never made time for it. Now that I find myself with some free time and the courage to share my personal experiences after 18 weeks of writing this daily microblog, I decided to give it a shot this year. Even if my entry is not selected as a winner, it feels good to finally submit something after years of waffling about it in my mind, yet doing nothing.

After a quiet stint in Salerno which recharged my batteries, I grabbed a train back to Naples. [Germana](https://jwn.gr/microblog/2017-08-25)'s good friend, Chiara, gave me a tour of [Scugnizzo Liberato](https://www.facebook.com/ScugnizzoLiberato/), an abandoned prison occupied by local community members in late 2015. They're progressively renovating the giant building, turning its walls into art studios, music rooms, and even a makeshift gym where Chiara practices trapeze. Occupations like this are becoming increasingly common in Naples, [spurred on by their mayor](http://politicalcritique.org/world/2017/in-naples-we-are-all-illegal-or-no-one-is/) who sees it as a unique form of democratic participation. From my perspective, the building seemed to be put to good use.

My American passport permits me to spend 90 days in Europe (well, technically just [Schengen countries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schengen_Area)) every 180 days without a visa. Today was day 90. Which means I needed to get out of the continent, although I would have gladly stayed longer. My next destination is Bangkok, Thailand. I visited Hanoi, Vietnam for work in 2016 and, after some initial culture shock, really enjoyed my time there. It inspired me to make Southeast Asia part of my worldwide trip. But it's unfortunately quite a distance from Europe, which made for a long day in the air.

My time in Bangkok is off to a rough start. I felt extremely groggy after being unable to sleep on the plane. That probably contributed to me forgetting my debit card in the airport ATM machine soon after landing. I didn’t recognize its absence until I was falling victim to a suit scam which, although elaborately orchestrated, should have been obvious to spot in hindsight. Short on cash, soaking wet from an evening downpour, and nursing a rumbling stomach from the mysterious street meat I ate for dinner, I called it an early night, hoping it'll be uphill from here.

After yesterday's misadventures, I decided to treat myself to a massage from one of the dozens of parlors nearby. The hourlong Thai massage cost me just 200 baht (~$6). Thailand in general is very inexpensive. My room at [Bed Station Hostel](https://www.bedstationhostel.com/en/index), one of the nicer hostels of the trip, is just 380 baht (~$12) per night. My delicious pad thai dinner was only 70 baht (~$2). The most expensive things are the tourist attractions, which I'm forgoing for now. Of all places to be low on cash and sans debit card, I could have picked worse.

I like to think that interacting with dozens of new people every week over the course of this trip has improved my ability to hold interesting conversation. There's a solid lesson my brain recently formalized: if you ask general questions, you'll get general answers; if you ask specific questions, you'll get specific answers. And a corollary: if you ask interesting questions, you'll get interesting answers. Asking good questions is sometimes all it takes to facilitate conversation. This has broad application to many life situations, a reason why I now try to actively remember this tip during all my conversations.

[Rattanakosin Island](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rattanakosin_Island), also known as Old Town, was absolutely overrun with people dressed in black long sleeves and pants, a baffling display on an extremely hot and muggy day. A local explained that Thais were headed to pay their respects to [their former king](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhumibol_Adulyadej), who will soon be cremated on the one year anniversary of his death. I stood out like a sore thumb as I navigated through the sea of black that overtook sidewalks and streets, on my way to visit many of Bangkok's most famous sites, including the [Grand Palace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grand_Palace) and the giant leaning Buddha at [Wat Pho](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wat_Pho).

A 30 minute train ride, a 40 minute walk, and a two minute forging of the Chao Phraya River by motor boat brought me to [Phra Pradaeng, Bangkok's "Green Lung."](https://www.wheresidewalksend.com/prapadaeng-green-lung-bangkok/) My next four hours comprised riding a rickety, rusted bicycle through the jungle, often along a raised sidewalk approximately a meter wide and with no railings to save me from a muddy demise. I had a slow lunch at [Bangkok Tree House](http://www.bangkoktreehouse.com/), a lush hotel seemingly materializing out of nowhere. After a stressful time in the concrete jungle of central Bangkok, I relished the tranquil beauty of the actual jungle.

Late September marks the tail end of monsoon season in this part of the world. Rain storms come at predictable times, with early afternoon and late night showers being the norm. The rain brings along lightning which blankets the foggy sky and thunder which reverberates in your chest. Rain falls in heavy sheets, growing in intensity beyond the point you'd consider reasonable. San Francisco doesn’t get storms like this, and their intensity exceeds what I remember from growing up in Pennsylvania and the Midwest. The storms are satisfying to watch, as long as I'm not stuck in the downpour.

Street vendors are everywhere in Bangkok, offering a prodigious variety of food and drinks. I've eaten fruits and vegetables I’ve never even seen before, let alone tasted. I've also consumed mystery meats that, upon further inspection, turn out to instead be organs I can only guess to be hearts and intestines. Large food markets are plentiful, and food carts line a multitude of streets, turning sidewalks into impromptu restaurants. Ordering is often challenging, involving a combination of pointing and mumbling. Sanitary policies are most definitely not enforced. The result is some incredibly cheap and delicious food.

There's a short comic I have in my browser bookmarks bar that I think about almost daily. It's called ["Amusing Ourselves to Death: Huxley vs Orwell"](http://highexistence.com/amusing-ourselves-to-death-huxley-vs-orwell/) and I suggest you take a minute to read it. Both *Brave New World* and *1984* grow more relevant with each passing day. Although they present markedly different dystopias, I increasingly see manifestations of both in my life. The world has changed drastically in recent years, with tech at the forefront. I'm far from a [Luddite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Luddite), but my eyes are opening to the negative aspects of technological innovation when put in the wrong hands.

I had enough with city life, so I headed down south to the beaches of Phuket, Thailand to meet up with my newest travel companion. [Mike](https://twitter.com/asciimike) is a former coworker from Firebase / Google and a close friend from back in San Francisco. We both had a lot to catch up on, which we did over some pineapple fried rice, panang chicken curry, and Chang beers, followed by a soak in the warm ocean waters. The two of us enjoy talking (and bitching) about similar life and work things, and it's entertaining to have someone to talk tech with again.

Mike and I spent the morning traveling to Krabi, a Thai province known for its limestone cliffs and pristine beaches. We made friends en route with Becky from the UK, who was headed to our same final destination of [Railay Beach](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Railay_Beach). The last leg was on a questionably seaworthy traditional [long-tail boat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Long-tail_boat). The craft was powered by a car engine mounted on its bow which drove a long driveshaft connected to a freely spinning propellor just meters behind the boat. The loud and wet ride offered striking views, and we spent the afternoon lounging on one of Thailand's nicest beaches.

I can think of few things as relaxing as floating belly up in the ocean in the middle of a monsoon, the waves lifting me up and down, forward and backwards, like a natural metronome. Submerging my head in the water, I could hear the hypnotic pitter patter of the rain as it repeatedly slammed against the surface of the water. Heavy rain may have prevented Mike, Becky, and I from going on our planned hike to the lagoon, but it didn't stop us from venturing to a secluded beach and enjoying some peaceful time in the water.

Getting my scuba diving certification last year has made traveling that much more enjoyable. Life is unbelievably vibrant just below the ocean's surface. Mike and I hopped on a long-tail boat this morning and headed out for a couple local island dives. Visibility was somewhat low due to the recent storms, but the water was warm and the marine life was plentiful. Coral, crabs, eels, rays, and countless species of fish were on full display, seeming to hardly notice us passing by. I expect this to be the first of many diving adventures as I travel around Southeast Asia.

For a while I was in a groove pumping out these daily posts. But I've lately found them increasingly harder to write. After five minutes staring at my computer today, I only managed to write "Mike and I took a ferry back to mainland Phuket." Part of the problem is people seem less interested with the posts each passing week. I also feel self-conscious that even after so many weeks, I have little to show beyond this microblog. At this point, I worry the trip is becoming a delay tactic, allowing me to avoid the question of what comes next.

Karon Beach is much busier and less remote than Railay Beach, reminiscent of many popular American beaches. Mike and I spent a relaxing day bodysurfing and getting sunburnt. We talked over Jack and coke from 7-Eleven in the evening as we awaited the arrival of Chad, a Notre Dame friend and former Seattle roommate. We convinced him to drop off his luggage and come with us to Bangla Road on Patong Beach, Phuket's major party spot. Becky joined us for what turned into what could either be considered a late night or an early morning. Either way, it was noteworthy.

Chad is taking over Mike's role as my travel buddy for the next two weeks. The three of us slept in for some much needed extra hours, waking just in time to grab lunch (so much pad thai!) followed by another round of Thai massages. Mike said his goodbyes as he headed off for some business in Bangkok, while Chad and I spent the day lounging on the beach until the rain chased us away. In the evening, we filled our bellies with various street foods from the temple night market. Just another typical day in paradise.

Despite yet another rainy day (which has honestly been every day), Chad and I did some sightseeing with the help of [Grab](https://www.grab.com/th/en/taxi/), the Uber of Southeast Asia. Highlights included [Wat Chalong](http://www.wat-chalong-phuket.com/), the largest of Phuket's dozens of temples. We also ascended a mountain to [Big Buddha](http://www.phuket-big-buddha.com/), a towering 45 meter concrete structure covered in marble. The fog unfortunately obscured most of its supposedly impressive 360 degree island views. A lack of cell coverage up there led to an adventurous tuk tuk ride back to Karon Beach. Phuket has more to offer than its beaches, but nothing is entirely a don't-miss.

Scuba diving can be exhausting. Beyond the obvious physical exertion of making your way through the water for fifty-ish minutes every dive, it takes a lot of mental energy to ensure your equipment is functioning properly, your air supply is sufficient, and your depth is within tolerable ranges. We were drained by the time we got back after three dives around the twin islands of [Ko Racha](https://wikitravel.org/en/Ko_Racha?title=Ko_Racha), situated a few miles off Phuket's southeastern coast. So naturally we decided to walk the two miles to and from another night market. I've got to get my steps in after all.

I didn't hear about the latest deadliest American mass shooting in Las Vegas until I was scrolling through Twitter this afternoon. Every day brings some new unnecessary killing or natural disaster or war crime or threat of nuclear annihilation or democratic crisis or on some days, all of the above. My brain isn't capable of reliably processing so many negative events. Prior generations of humans rarely knew about issues outside their local communities. How can I possibly deal with all the terrible things I know are happening across the span of 8 billion humans, or even just 320 million Americans?

I was going to use today’s post to discuss how stupidly ineffective airport security has been during my trip after my blunted travel scissors were confiscated in the Vietnam airport because they "could cut things." And then Chad and I spent the day touring around the incredible, video game-like sights of [Angkor Archaeological Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Angkor) outside Siem Reap, Cambodia, so I figured I'd write about that. But then I succumbed to food poisoning and dehydration and found myself puking over the walls of a nearly thousand year old temple. Some days are too hard to fit into 100 words.

In an curious quirk of monetary policy, the US dollar happens to be Cambodia's de facto currency. A street vendor on Pub Street just outside our hotel which sold chicken fried rice for $1.50 accepted two greenbacks as payment. To add to the intrigue, the vendor didn't give back American change since Cambodia is a coinless society. Instead, they produced a 2,000 riel note, Cambodia's local currency which is much weaker than the dollar. It's strange to use American money in such a foreign land, but I do appreciate the short break from the mental overhead of constantly converting currencies.

I turned 10,000 days old today. This worldwide trip started on day 9,850 of my life, at which point I had visited 9 countries (🇺🇸🇨🇦🇲🇽🇮🇳🇪🇸🇮🇹🇯🇵🇻🇳🇰🇷). But in the past 150 days, I've been to 16 countries, 11 of which were new (🇵🇹🇫🇷🇲🇨🇱🇺🇧🇪🇳🇱🇩🇪🇸🇪🇩🇰🇹🇭🇰🇭), bringing my total country count to 20 (an increase of 222% in just the last 1.50% of my life)! I spent my metric birthday visiting more incredible temples along Angkor Archeological Park's Grand Circuit. In the evening, I attended [Phare](https://pharecircus.org/), the Cambodian Circus, an acrobatics show which, although a far cry from Cirque du Soleil, was quite entertaining.

Chad and I took a day trip to the floating village of [Kompong Khleang](https://www.kompongkhleang.org/). A nonprofit called [Bridge of Life](http://www.bridgeoflifeschool.org/) uses this tour's proceeds to provide educational and community wellness programming in Cambodia. Tours simultaneously increase their exposure and provide an alternate revenue stream beyond charitable donations. The day trip, guided by a young man born in the village, earned top marks from us. It, in addition to last night's circus organized by a separate nonprofit, spurred me to consider if [Communities Rising](https://jwn.gr/microblog/2017-06-29) could do something similar, although our work doesn't happen anywhere near a tourist area like Siem Reap.

Walking around downtown Siem Reap, as well as other Southeast Asia cities I've visited, is sensory overload. Smells of cooking food and vehicle exhaust permeate the air. My eyes work to identify obstacles along the sidewalk as vendors shove shirts, jewelry, and artwork in my face. [Fried ice cream](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stir-fried_ice_cream) vendors shout deals at me as I walk by already eating a competitor's offering. Tuk tuk drivers brush my arm or shoulder as I pass by, seeking my business. Thankfully, as my brain improves its ability to filter this giant stream of data, I feel increasingly comfortable in this frenetic environment.

Chad and I arrived in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam past midnight after a hectic airport experience during which our flight was canceled and subsequently uncanceled, resulting in us having the front ten rows to ourselves. The city is in constant motion. Crossing the wide downtown streets is an exercise in trust with hundreds of motorbikes weaving around us. We enjoyed pho in the bustling [Ben Thanh Market](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/B%E1%BA%BFn_Th%C3%A0nh_Market) before sampling some — okay, quite a few — craft brews at [Heart of Darkness](http://heartofdarknessbrewery.com/) brewery, capping the night with doing laundry above a bitcoin cafe near the nightlife street of [Pham Ngu Lao](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ph%E1%BA%A1m_Ng%C5%A9_L%C3%A3o_Street).

It’s somewhat strange to be in Vietnam knowing [the United States fought a war here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vietnam_War) just over 40 years ago. To learn more about the war, we visited the [Cu Chi tunnels](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C%E1%BB%A7_Chi_tunnels), an immense network of connecting underground tunnels used by the Viet Cong as part of their guerrilla warfare tactics against the Americans. The tour started uncomfortably with a heavily anti-American propaganda video about the tunnels, but, as they say, history is written by the victors. Squatting — and at points crawling — through the tunnels was eerie and claustrophobic, but helped me comprehend the lengths soldiers go through in wartime.

In the midst of a day trip on the [Mekong Delta](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mekong_Delta), I learned [my entry for Notre Dame Magazine's essay contest](https://jwn.gr/microblog/2017-09-12) was not selected. The failure is disappointing, but it won't deter me from writing. This trip has provided ample time to reflect on other failures from these past few years. From prioritizing work over spending time with my ex-girlfriend to holding grudges at work because I took business decisions as personal slights, I recognize my unhappiness and frustrations were often fruits of my own personal failings. It's up to me to use those failings as fuel for future success.

I woke up to an alert about the US men’s national soccer team failing to qualify for the 2018 World Cup, a first in my lifetime. Of all possible sporting results, seeing the US win the World Cup is at the very top for me. Given the event is held every four years, I’ll optimistically be alive for only 15 or so more of them. And that makes this embarrassing failure even more devastating. Despite pumping oodles of money into the association and some minor successes at recent World Cups, it feels like my dream is quite far from reality.

Chad took an early morning flight home and, just like that, I was back to solo travel. Vietnam has a well-worn backpacking route from Ho Chi Minh City in the south to Hanoi up north. Instead of planning several days or weeks in advance as I've mostly done so far, I'm embracing the true backpacker spirit of booking last-minute accommodations. A short plane ride north took me to my first stop along the route, the beach town of Nha Trang. Lethargy and stomach cramps were my travel partners, resulting in an early bed time in hopes of sleeping them off.

I arose from a twelve hour rest feeling not quite perfect, but decent enough to do some exploring. The main attractions in Nha Trang other than the beach are a few temples and a sizable market. To be honest, I’ve already seen my fair share of temples and markets for the trip. Similarly to what happened with European churches, I've reached the point where it becomes hard to distinguish new ones from the dozens I've seen before. There are of course exceptions (e.g., [Angkor Wat](https://jwn.gr/microblog/2017-10-03), [Milan’s Duomo](https://jwn.gr/microblog/2017-08-29)), but the ones here are definitely not amongst them.

I’ve had a loner mindset these past few days. After traveling with Mike and then Chad for so many weeks straight, I just wanted some alone time, which I was not getting at my hostel or around Nha Trang. I found some solitude at the Ba Ho pools north of the city, seeing no more than two dozen other people my entire time there. The hike involved some daunting rock parkour, but the payoff of floating motionless in a refreshing pool as waterfalls crashed nearby and fish nipped softly at my skin was well worth the trek.

Vietnamese hostels operate differently from those elsewhere. The bedrooms are similar, packed tight with bunk beds and storage lockers. But instead of paying for things up front or as you use them, you accrue a tab during your stay. And every night there's a "family dinner," where you enjoy an unreasonably large amount of food with your hostel mates for just a few dollars. And of course there is the *free beer* happy hour, which is exactly as it sounds, although it tastes like the watered-down crap I drank in college. But hey, it's hard to argue with free beer.

A common topic of discussion with other travelers in Nha Trang was other places that are better than Nha Trang. One location I heard enthusiastic reviews for was Da Lat, a mountain town a four hour bus ride to the southeast. I still plan to move north towards Hanoi, but my gut convinced me to take the slight backtrack. That spontaneous decision is already paying dividends after just one evening here. It's a calmer, greener place than my prior stops in Vietnam, and I appreciated not sweating away half my body weight as I walked along the town's large lake.

I try to never say I don't have time for something. The truth is often instead that I don't *make* time for it. I will always feel busy. I have nearly no commitments and spend my days visiting places like Pongour Waterfall, yet I still find myself "too busy" to write 100 words, make my current project mobile-friendly, or respond to that email I've been meaning to for the past month. Like air in a room, busy-ness expands to fill whatever space I give it. If I'm too busy to do something, I'm simply not prioritizing it properly.

[They](http://highlandsporttravel.com/) suggested not looking down at the waterfall, so of course that was the first thing I did after getting roped in. I had already slid down one waterfall and leaped off another, so I was ready to abseil directly into this one. The "Washing Machine" spun me around like a load of laundry, forcefully depositing me into the river below. For a few seconds I didn’t know which way was up, not that I could swim through the heavy current even if I did. My head eventually bobbed to the surface, wishing I could have another go.

After a few too many drinks at the ingenious [Maze Bar](https://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/Restaurant_Review-g293922-d6948253-Reviews-Duong_Len_Trang_Cafe_Tram_Mai-Da_Lat_Lam_Dong_Province.html) last night, I wasn’t in ideal shape to wake up for my planned morning hike. I instead opted to work out of a cafe before jumping on a 14 hour evening sleeper bus headed for Hoi An. The reclining seats were equal parts disgusting and dysfunctional. Some had no clip, others had two buckles, even more had belts with nothing on the end. My life was in the driver’s hands as we barreled along mountain roads. It wasn't until long after sunset that I forced myself to sleep.

Hoi An was almost universally praised by fellow backpackers traveling Vietnam in the opposite direction than I. After a day here, I understand why — it is quaint as fuck. And that's saying nothing of its pristine beaches. Streets and building facades are strung with lanterns that only get more charming after sundown. The market is packed with stands selling delicious local dishes like [cao lau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cao_l%E1%BA%A7u) and [white rose](http://hoianfoodtour.com/white-rose-hoi-an/). And biking through rice paddies as far as the eye can see outside the town provides the stereotypical views of friendly local farmers in [conical hats](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asian_conical_hat) doing their daily work.

People often underestimate how likely it is for some unlikely event to happen to them. It's the same reason why the [birthday paradox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birthday_problem) seems so surprising at first glance. A specific random event may be unlikely to happen, but given the sheer number of unlikely events that could possibly occur, it's actually probable some unlikely event will come to pass. Yet when that event does happen, people like to attribute it to fate or maybe even God's will. But maybe that random event is just that, a coincidence bound to happen when you sit down and look at the odds.

Amongst my regular social media doses of Notre Dame football hype and Trump’s childish feuds, the [#MeToo hashtag](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Me_too_(hashtag)) has been popping up across my feeds. It’s one thing to hear about the sexual assault of a famous actor, athlete, or musician. It’s another when it’s high school friends, former co-workers, and relatives. I of course know the statistics, but so often statistics are divorced from reality. I applaud the courage of those speaking out to illuminate these issues for people like myself. To them and the others who remain silent, I want you to know you are never alone.

There have been a handful of special moments over the course of this trip when I realize how different my life is now compared to what it was back in California. Doing 50 miles per hour in the pouring rain dressed like a smurf in a ridiculous blue rain jacket on the back of a motorcycle driven by Mr. Phu over the [Hai Van Pass](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H%E1%BA%A3i_V%C3%A2n_Pass) (Vietnam’s Highway 1) en route to Hue was most definitely one of those moments. An experience I didn’t even know existed just days prior, it turned out to be a day I won't soon forget.

I enjoyed yesterday's ride so much that I asked Mr. Phu to drive me today around Hue, the nation's capital prior to the Vietnam War. Instead, a man who claimed to be Mr. Phu's brother — yet most certainly was not — greeted me this morning. We endured the on and off rain as he took me by scooter to see ornate tombs of past emperors, an American bunker overrun with weeds and cows, an abandoned water park that sadly was blocked by a government official unwilling to take a bribe, and the already crumbling [Imperial City](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imperial_City,_Hu%E1%BA%BF) where emperors lived and worked.

Choosing today's photo was damn near impossible, but I ended up going with my nearly naked self riding a water buffalo named Donald Trump taking a dump. I arrived in Phong Nha, Vietnam last night and joined Natalia and Meredith, two San Francisco natives I keep running across. The day started with the massively breathtaking [Phong Nha Cave](http://phongnhatourism.com.vn/en/phong-nha-cave/). But it was outshone by [Duck Stop](https://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/Attraction_Review-g4014591-d12878877-Reviews-The_Duck_Stop-Phong_Nha_Ke_Bang_National_Park_Quang_Binh_Province.html), where we played with ducks and rode that infamous water buffalo. I was impressed and inspired by their ability to transform a small, rural Vietnamese farm into a unique business whose weirdness makes it great.

Natalia explained the concept of [passive participant observation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Participant_observation) to me as a chicken was caught and killed in front of our eyes. While sharing drinks with the Duck Stop crew last night at our energetic hostel, [Easy Tiger](http://www.easytigerhostel.com/), they invited the three of us over to the farm for lunch today. We got a little more than we bargained for, including some bicycle malfunctions and a firsthand view of how food is prepared in this part of the world. After a morning hike in the jungle, we appreciated the gracious offering of food, beer, and views from our new friends.

The towering limestone cliffs and heavy rainfall in Phong Nha and the surrounding [Ke Bang National Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phong_Nha-K%E1%BA%BB_B%C3%A0ng_National_Park) combine to litter the area with hundreds of caves and underground rivers, including the world's largest known cave. Camille, a Parisian I met last night in the hostel, drove me around the park, shrouded in thick forest like that of Jurassic Park. Along the route, we zip-lined into [Dark Cave](http://phongnhatourism.com.vn/en/dark-cave/), where we covered ourselves with mud in its pitch black, waist-high mud baths. We also trekked for over an hour inside the gorgeous [Paradise Cave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thi%C3%AAn_%C4%90%C6%B0%E1%BB%9Dng_Cave), by far the largest cave I've ever explored.

Another lengthy sleeper bus ride left me in Ninh Binh, Vietnam at 4 AM. Despite not booking anything, my homestay for the following night graciously let me crash in their living room and fed me a huge breakfast. A full day bike ride felt like traveling through the pages of National Geographic, with empty rice paddies reflecting massive limestone cliffs on a perfectly overcast day. Somewhat surprisingly, my three weeks so far in Vietnam (plus last year's trip to Hanoi) makes it my third-most frequented country, behind only the US and Spain. It's beauty continues to exceed any prior expectations.

I've been moving quickly through Vietnam and have come to terms with the fact that I won't create anything substantial while traveling like this. I do still spend time working on projects, but my mentality has shifted. Instead of stressing about my next career move, I’m honing my skills through projects I enjoy and appreciating the experiences and people each day brings. It's not exactly what I envisioned for this trip, but my career will always be there when I'm ready for it. I may never have a trip like this again, so I best make the most of it.

Rock climbing is one of those activities that uses muscles I didn't know existed. I arrived on Cat Ba Island yesterday afternoon and immediately booked myself a [full day kayaking and rock climbing tour](http://www.asiaoutdoors.com.vn/top-rope-rock-climbing.html) in Lan Ha Bay, which features the same impressive limestone cliffs as Phong Nha, just surrounded by water instead of more land. It was my first time rock climbing outside, a much different beast than the indoor climbing I've done before. The real rocks did a number on my arms and legs, but the marvelous views at the tops of the ascents beat any gym's views.

Some days it's hard to be abroad, so far away from the people and things I care about. Notre Dame football game days, birthday parties, product launches, holiday festivities. Today was one of those days I spent homesick, or maybe just nostalgic, wishing I could join my Halloween costumed friends back home and my former co-workers celebrating a well-earned feature release in Amsterdam. I did enjoy a strenuous morning hike in [Cat Ba National Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/C%C3%A1t_B%C3%A0_National_Park) with some new friends, but I would have gladly traded today's beautiful sights for a chance to shoot the shit with my college buddies.

After six months of what has largely felt like perpetual summer, the brisk mountain air in Sa Pa, Vietnam momentarily confused my senses. I arrived in the town, situated just 35 km south of China, at 2 AM after a twelve hour bus ride. Unlike prior rides, I made sure to book a room for the night, "splurging" on a private hotel room ($10 per night instead of a $5 hostel dorm) to facilitate some quality sleep and a clean shower. I sorely needed both after the bus. The good rest kickstarted a relaxing day spent catching up on life.

Rice is by far Sa Pa's largest export. But it is the region's second largest export which brings travelers to this remote part of Vietnam. And that would be its stunning views. My eyes took in plenty of those today on a hiking tour through the seemingly endless rice paddies dotting mountains and valleys alike. The tour brought me through several villages inhabited by Vietnam's various ethnic minority groups, always selling a variety of handmade crafts and clothing. I relished the opportunity to walk with and learn from locals who helped explain life in this different part of the country.

Watching fog swallow mountain tops from the peak of [Mount Fansipan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fansipan) reminded me how life is often about making the best of non-ideal situations. Appreciation for the clear skies I saw from the cable car turned into disappointment as heavy fog and wind rolled in up high. I debated not climbing the final 600 steps to the highest peak in all of Indochina, worried my view would be obscured by a blanket of fog. But up I went. And although the rice paddies sadly weren't visible, the view I got was beautiful in its own way and worth the climb.

Hanoi provided my introductory taste of Southeast Asia a year ago. Returning to the city for a short stopover brought back the culture shock from that first visit. The city has a hectic, “watch-out-for-your-life” pace that grows on your over time. In the midst of the mania, I found [my favorite pho place](https://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/Restaurant_Review-g293924-d1124697-Reviews-Pho_Thin-Hanoi.html) from my prior trip, a fitting last meal after an incredible month in Vietnam. I hopped on a short evening flight to the next stop on my worldwide trip: Luang Prabang, Laos. Vietnam lifted my spirits and I hope to carry those feelings on into Laos.

If Laos is known for anything, it has to be its stunning waterfalls. The first one up for me was the majestic [Kuang Si Falls](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kuang_Si_Falls), which looked how I imagine the Garden of Eden would. Multi-tiered pools of vibrant turquoise water overflowing into the forest floor, a towering 60 meter cascade roaring in the distance. I of course jumped in the crisp water, marveling at nature's very own infinity pools from underneath the pounding water of a minor fall. This is the first of many waterfalls I’ll come across in Laos, but it’s going to be damn hard to beat.

I spent a majority of my day at [Utopia](https://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/Restaurant_Review-g295415-d1552033-Reviews-Utopia_Restaurant_and_Bar-Luang_Prabang_Luang_Prabang_Province.html), an open air restaurant bar overlooking the Mekong River and featuring sunrise yoga, beach volleyball, an extensive drink menu, and cushioned mats for lounging atop its bamboo floors. Oh, and strong Wi-Fi, which gives it a few bonus points in my book. Its chill, laid-back vibe is a perfect microcosm for the rest of Luang Prabang. The city, like the river I spent much of the day peering at over my computer screen, appears to move in slow motion. It’s a welcome change from the fast-paced style of life in Vietnam.

I’ve rarely woken up early enough to catch a sunrise on this trip. I've been more likely to be awake at that hour due to travel to a new destination or still being out from the prior night. But today I forced myself out of bed at 5:30 AM and climbed [Mount Phou Si](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phou_si), a big hill in central Luang Prabang offering scenic views of the town and the surrounding mountains. The bright orange glow off the morning clouds provided a great start to a day highlighted by visiting [Tad Sae Falls](https://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/Attraction_Review-g295415-d454895-Reviews-Tad_Sae_Waterfall-Luang_Prabang_Luang_Prabang_Province.html), where I came face-to-face with some elephants.

[Visiting local farms](https://jwn.gr/microblog/2017-10-25) is quickly becoming one of my favorite travel experiences. This morning it was [Living Land Rice Farm](https://www.backstreetacademy.com/luang-prabang/154/rice-farming), where I learned firsthand how to plant, grow, harvest, clean, and cook rice. From ploughing a rice paddy in knee deep mud with Rudolph the water buffalo to using traditional Lao machines and some muscle to grind rice into flour, it was an informative experience which left a big smile on my face. As someone with a career possible from the comfort of a couch, experiences like this give me an appreciation for those whose jobs require backbreaking manual labor.

I arose early to embark on a two day "slow boat" journey up the Mekong River, destined for the border town of Huay Xai, stopping over in Pakbeng. Travelers typically make this trip in the opposite direction, crossing over from northern Thailand to ride the current of Laos' muddy brown river into Luang Prabang. My boat carried a handful of backpackers alongside a rotating cast of locals hopping on and off at various riverside villages. It was a lazy day spent catching up on my reading list and podcasts, enjoying the landscapes, and reflecting on a frenetic past few weeks.

Day two of the 205 mile (330 km) boat ride to Huay Xai featured more water buffalo bathing in the river and goats balancing precariously along limestone cliffs. But the sight of a sleeping young boy no older than ten held my attention most strongly. His shaved head and vibrant orange robe told me he, like roughly one third of all Lao males at some point in their lives, was a monk. I struggled to imagine myself being born into his life, a common sensation I feel when interacting with locals whose lives are so vastly different from my own.

The main attraction in Huay Xai is [The Gibbon Experience](https://www.gibbonexperience.org/), a unique trekking and zip lining trip with overnight accommodation in the world’s highest tree houses. Although more expensive than most activities in Southeast Asia, I couldn't pass up this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity. I chose the three day, two night [waterfall tour](https://www.gibbonexperience.org/waterfall/) since it involved more trekking and zipping with stays in two different tree houses. The first day did not disappoint, culminating in a 500 meter zip line featuring a surreal view of a rainbow emerging from the endless mountains as I cruised high above the forest in light rain.

The tree houses, situated up to 40 meters above the forest floor, are only accessible by zip line. Each one is an imposing, multi-level structure featuring a full bathroom, a dining table with stools, running, drinkable water, mattresses and pillows protected under heavy mosquito nets (which keep out other tree dwellers like spiders and rats), and, of course, stunning 360 degree views of the surrounding forest. The open air structures comfortably and safely held our group of eight. Falling asleep high in the trees, listening to the surprisingly loud din of the nighttime forest was a truly extraordinary experience.

Long days of trekking and zip lining left me and the rest of my group with little energy by sunset. We were in bed early both nights, making it easier to wake up in time for today's sunrise. Not that I could actually see anything! I was greeted by a thick wall of fog hugging the forest canopy, thin films of water coating zip lines which seemingly disappeared just a few arm lengths away. I enjoyed an hour of uninterrupted time watching sunlight fight its way through the cloud cover, soaking in my last few hours in this unique lodging.

I arrived in Luang Namtha, Laos last night after yet another harrowing bus ride. I had planned to do a trekking tour here, but sore muscles and anxiety over a growing list of neglected life responsibilities prompted me to stay inside for most of the day. In the evening, I read [a post about creativity and productivity](https://kottke.org/17/11/the-tension-between-creativity-and-productivity) on [Jason Kotke’s incredibly entertaining blog](https://kottke.org/) which crystallized some of my recent thoughts in a way that I couldn't formulate in my mind. David Allen's recommendation of "deliberate, mindful prioritization" is a critical concept I will keep in mind as my travels continue.

"This too shall pass." That's something I've repeated to myself throughout this trip. The phrase, [tracing back to a Persian adage](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/This_too_shall_pass), has become a sort of life philosophy for me. Those four little words remind me that life, as well as its constituent ups and downs, are ephemeral. Bad times, like the asocial, brooding mood I find myself in as I travel a northern loop through Laos, won't afflict me forever. Similarly, good times should be savored since who knows what tomorrow will bring. Believing my current human condition is permanent not only extends bad times, it shortens good ones.

Two dozen travelers and locals, along with their belongings and a cage of chickens, most certainly put today's boat over capacity for the four hour journey to Muang Ngoi. The ride left my shoes soaked and body sore, although it also provided incredible views of the river cutting through giant, jungle-covered limestone mountains as we arrived into town. Muang Ngoi is only accessible by water and comprises a single dirt road packed with guest houses, restaurants, and bars, mostly catering to tourists. Hammocks and Beerlao are plentiful in this picturesque town which has the perfect balance of activity and silence.

High atop Muang Ngoi, waiting for the early morning fog to dissipate, I felt a pang of cognitive dissonance. In many ways, my life is about minimizing discomfort. Money brings the comfort of security, friends the comfort of togetherness, a girlfriend the comfort of intimacy. Yet I also believe comfort breeds complacency, explaining why I consistently uproot my life once it gets too comfortable in search of a higher local maximum of comfort. Will I ever accept my current comfort as good enough, or am I doomed to indefinitely look for more, never stopping to appreciate what I've already achieved?

An epic travel day seems like the right time to discuss Lao transportation, where each trip could be my last. A one hour morning trip to Nong Khiaw on a barely seaworthy boat was followed by back-to-back four hour minivan rides to Luang Prabang onto Vang Vieng which were driven at dangerous speeds along pockmarked mountainside roads. At least one person puked on each leg and last week's minivan even ran over a stray dog. And don't even get me started about bus stations being intentionally located well outside city centers. I never imagined I'd miss SF MUNI so much.

Vang Vieng is no longer the hedonistic backpacker playground it's known to be due to [2012 police crackdowns](https://www.independent.co.uk/travel/asia/how-vang-vieng-in-laos-has-worked-hard-to-improve-its-dangerous-reputation-a6897616.html). It's been reborn as a hotbed for outdoor activities, a fitting pivot given the town's breathtaking surroundings. Its most iconic activity — barhopping down the riverside in inner tubes — is legal once again, just significantly toned down. And you'll still find some restaurants offering a special "happy" menu. So, naturally, I spent my first day here doing nothing in particular, instead going on my own barhop in search of coffee shops and restaurants with solid WiFi, as opposed to bars with cheap drinks.

I took a full day tour of Vang Vieng's major highlights: tubing with a headlamp through the dark, low-ceilinged Water Cave, quickly walking through the unimpressive Elephant Cave (Vietnam's caves have clearly spoiled me), kayaking down the Nam Song River surrounded by drunk tubers, and playing in the cool waters of Blue Lagoon. The chill vibes found in Luang Prabang permeate Vang Vieng as well. Lao people rarely seem to be in a hurry, which makes even jam-packed tour days like today seem leisurely. While the lax attitudes sometimes get on my impatient nerves, they were quite welcome today.

Per capita, [Laos is the world's most bombed country](http://legaciesofwar.org/about-laos/secret-war-laos/). During the Vietnam War, the USA dropped a jaw-dropping quarter ton of bombs on Laos *on average for each of its seven million citizens*. An estimated 30% of bombs never detonated. These unexploded ordnances (UXOs) continue to maim and kill locals to this day. I spent today traveling to Phonsavan in northeast Laos, smack dab in the center of what looks like a giant blood splat on charts mapping the bombings. Bomb shells repurposed as everything from trash cans to house stilts to interior decor are a sobering reminder of war.

I’m particularly drawn to the works of Christopher Nolan (*Inception*, *The Prestige*, *Memento*) and David Lindelof (*Lost*, *The Leftovers*) due to their willingness to leave questions unanswered. Pondering theories explaining their cliffhangers is what makes their work especially memorable. I feel the same about the [Plain of Jars](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plain_of_Jars), a landscape spotted with clusters of giant stone jars carved during the Iron Age. Today I visited sites 1, 2, and 3, soaking in theories about their purpose, ranging from brewing liquor to burials. But evidence is lacking, and that’s okay. After all, the mystery is the reason I’m here.

Turkey is unfortunately not a very popular meat option in Laos. But I was able to find a donor kebab stand selling turkey wraps for an impromptu Thanksgiving meal along the banks of the Mekong River in Vientiane. I didn't mind the solitude after spending the prior night on a sleeper bus where I legitimately shared a bed with a random Lao dude. Despite being the capital city, there’s not a lot to do here. I saw all the major sites today, including some temples and the bizarre [Buddha Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Buddha_Park). It was a unique Thanksgiving that felt far from normal.

Day 200 of the worldwide trip was spent entirely in transit to the remote Kong Lor Cave. I read ["The Western Elite From A Chinese Perspective,"](https://americanaffairsjournal.org/2017/11/western-elite-chinese-perspective/) an insightful article providing an outside perspective on my culture. I particularly liked Puzhong's comment that "we should neither become too excited by what we have achieved nor too depressed by what we failed to achieve." It's cliche to say "If you work hard, you’ll succeed; if you don't, you’ll fail." But it's increasingly clear to me the latter rings much truer than the former, hard work being necessary, but not sufficient, for success.

Although [Kong Lor Cave](https://wikitravel.org/en/Konglor) is known as a must-see destination in Laos, it is truly in the middle of nowhere. I debated whether or not to visit given my [recent caving adventures in Phong Nha, Vietnam](https://jwn.gr/microblog/locations/phong-nha), but I’m glad I did. A tiny boat took me and a fellow French backpacker through the 7 km deep cave with mammoth openings on both ends. Headlamps were the only light sources, outside of an exquisite fully lit walking section. The experience of speeding through the cave was exhilarating, as if I was traveling into the belly of a giant monster.

I haven’t pre-booked accommodations in Laos as I typically have no issues finding a hostel or guesthouse with cheap rooms available upon arriving. But after a fourth straight day spent traveling at least six hours, my stubbornness caused trouble in Pakse. Most places were fully booked, but I found a hotel room for $25 per night. After traveling so cheaply across Southeast Asia for the past three months, I balked at the price, eventually finding another place for half that cost after much searching. The experience left me tired and frustrated, a poor and irrational tradeoff for $13 in savings.

I try to understand the basics about countries I visit, reading up on histories and learning words like "hello" and "thank you." I also attempt to responsibly interact with locals. Today I toured the [Bolaven Plateau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bolaven_Plateau), an elevated region in southern Laos home to many local ethnic groups and waterfalls. The waterfalls were great, but visits to two local villages left a bad taste in my mouth. The tour offered no way to buy goods to support the tribes nor to even interact with them. These villages should not be zoos for foreigners to visit to snap their Instagram pictures.

Laos is a landlocked country, nuzzled between China to the north, Vietnam to the east, Cambodia to the south, and Thailand to the west. Despite that, its southernmost tip is called [Si Phan Don](https://wikitravel.org/en/Si_Phan_Don) ("Four Thousand Islands"), a unique landform arising from the meandering of the Mekong River. Most islands are small and uninhabited, but a few are large enough to support communities. Don Det is one of those, a well known backpacking paradise whose remoteness adds to its allure. After so much transit in the prior weeks, I’m bumming out here until my Lao visa expires next week.

*"Bum of Don Det"* ([*"Fresh Prince of Bel-Air"*](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3qHA366oRMs) parody)

 

Now this is a story all about how,

My trip got flipped, turned upside down.

And I’d like to take a minute, just don’t you fret,

I’ll tell you how I became the bum of a town called Don Det.

 

All across Laos, on a traveling craze,

On public transit is where I spent most of my days.

Packin' tight, maxin’, definitely not chill,

Praying boats don’t sink nor buses spill.

When a local Lao guy who was looking quite sour,

Decided we should share a bed the next dozen hours.

One of many journeys I hoped to soon forget,

I said, "Won’t be long 'til I relax in Don Det."

 

I booked one last bus, and when it came near,

The plate said "4K" and it had Buddha in the mirror.

If anything I could say this bus was suspect,

But I thought, "Nah, forget it. Yo homes, to Don Det."

 

I pulled up to the island around two or three,

And I yelled to the bartender, "Yo homes, *sabaidee*."

I looked at my bungalow, I was finally set,

To lay on my hammock as the Bum of Don Det.

Other than boats, kayaks provide the most effective way to see the Four Thousand Islands. Just don't get pulled too far downstream into [Khone Phapheng Falls](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khone_Phapheng_Falls), the widest in all of Southeast Asia. I managed to avoid that rough ride on a full day kayak tour along the Mekong River, featuring plenty of waterfalls, a BBQ lunch and some sand soccer on one of the many minor islands, and a few quick glances at one of the rare freshwater [Irrawaddy dolphins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Irrawaddy_dolphin) which call this place home. Sunset views from a hammock — Beerlao in hand — were my rewards for today's exercise.

My mind desires rationality. It's helped me excel in school and explains why I'm drawn to math and science, where things generally are expressed using well-defined formulae. And it frames my passion for programming, where things like designing efficient algorithms and simplifying complex user interactions light up my brain's pleasure center. But rationality has its drawbacks. I'm befuddled and dismayed by our current political and social cultures where tribalism trumps — or, maybe "Trumps" — facts. And it causes strife in relationships, since my mind and my heart aren't always on the same page. It seems being rational is sometimes irrational.

The overland border crossing between Laos and Cambodia is one of the most corrupt in the world. From my bus driver offering a service to skip the entire visa process to Lao officials illegally requesting money for my exit stamp to Cambodian officials charging fees for bogus "health checks," the border crossing requires a lot of patience, determination, and a few extra dollars on top of the standard visa cost. After well over an hour and threats from Lao and Cambodian officials saying I would never be allowed to leave or enter their countries, respectively, I had returned to Cambodia.

[My prior trip to Cambodia](https://jwn.gr/microblog/locations/siem-reap) was brief, so I'm back to see more of the country. First up is Kratie, a little town on the Mekong which is silent by 8 PM. Tourists are few and far between, giving me more than enough reason to spend the day alone working on my computer. But I did get out this afternoon, biking north to Kampi — with a Frenchman I met on the bus from Laos — to see more Irrawaddy dolphins. The larger population here led to some incredible close encounters, although I still struggled to catch the quick creatures on camera.

I've mostly avoided discussing US politics on this microblog. But that is a bit disingenuous given how often it's on my mind. The daily coming to terms with a Trump presidency certainly takes a toll on my well-being. As stories of border walls, healthcare repeals, corporate tax cuts, and pedophilic congressmen continually stream in, I often revisit an article called ["I Don’t Know How To Explain To You That You Should Care About Other People."](https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/i-dont-know-how-to-explain-to-you-that-you-should_us_59519811e4b0f078efd98440) It's one of those rare pieces which gracefully pieces together my own jumbled thoughts. Empathy is severely lacking in our homes, offices, schools, and governments.

I continued south along the Mekong River's meandering path to Kampong Cham, yet another town situated on the banks of the world's 12th longest river. I quickly left the French colonial downtown for my homestay in the countryside. Upon arriving, I was ferried onto a boat for a sunset fishing trip, during which I attempted to catch fish by casting a weighted net into the river. The Mekong may just be a temporary companion on my journey, but for the people here, it's their lifeblood. That's fortunate for me, as my lifelong streak of never catching a fish continued.

[OBT](http://www.obtchiro.com/) is a Cambodian-run NGO dedicated to the education and empowerment of children living in Chiro village, just a few kilometers from Kampong Cham. The homestay I'm staying at, consisting of a bamboo dormitory and four private bamboo bungalows, is one of the NGO's revenue streams. Their premium [Sky Bungalow](http://www.obtchiro.com/sky-bungalow/), complete with a private bathroom and loft, runs me $13 a night. The bungalow is one of the few calm spots on the OBT premises, frolicking children and animals constantly overflowing into the surrounding classrooms and crop fields, a handful of Western volunteers providing some organization to the chaos.

I haven’t been a huge fan of Cambodian food. Surrounded by countries whose cuisines I particularly enjoy, it seems bland and uninspired in comparison. But while staying at OBT, I've had the opportunity dine in local houses. And those fresh home cooked meals have been delicious! Plus I appreciate the experience of eating alongside locals and knowing my money goes directly to a family in need. And thanks to the OBT school just down the road, many of the children at these houses speak English well enough to hold a conversation and explain more of their culture to me.

There isn’t a ton to do around Kampong Cham, beyond visiting the ruins of [Nokor Wat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Banteay_Prey_Nokor) (a miniature [Angkor Wat](https://jwn.gr/microblog/2017-10-03)), scaling the relatively small Pros and Srey Mountains, and climbing the abandoned French lighthouse. Having already done those things, I rented a bicycle today to cross the world's longest bamboo bridge to Koh Pen Island. However, the bamboo bridge, which had to be rebuilt after it washed away every rainy season, was recently replaced with a permanent concrete one. A minor bummer for me, but surely a huge improvement for locals living on either side of the bridge.

After a long stretch without visitors, I headed to Phnom Penh, Cambodia's capital, to meet up with my friend [Caleb](https://twitter.com/calebatwd) Since he had a late flight, I headed to a tiny movie theater in the evening to watch ["First They Killed My Father,"](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_They_Killed_My_Father_(film)) a 2017 Angelina Jolie-directed film documenting one girl's experience during the Cambodian genocide. The tragic story filled in a lot of gaps I had about the [Khmer Rouge](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khmer_Rouge), the name given to Cambodian communists, who carried out the genocide. Viewing a film like that in the place where the events happened made it that much more impactful.

On April 17, 1975, the Khmer Rouge evacuated the entirety of Phnom Penh. Over the course of the next four years, they [brutally murdered 1.7 million people](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cambodian_genocide) — a shocking quarter of the entire country — through work, starvation, and torture. Caleb and I contemplated this terrible chapter in human history as we visited [Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tuol_Sleng_Genocide_Museum) (a school turned torture and execution center) and [Choeung Ek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Choeung_Ek) (an orchard turned mass grave and the best-known of the Killing Fields). It was an extremely somber way to kick off Caleb's trip, but learning history is important to ensure we never repeat it.

After a morning visit to the [Royal Palace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Palace,_Phnom_Penh), Caleb got introduced to transportation in Southeast Asia inside a hot van packed with locals and topped off with a puking child. Our destination was Kampot, a riverside town in southern Cambodia, where we've booked [a bamboo bungalow overlooking the Mekong](http://samonvillagekampot.com/). Caleb is a fellow Notre Dame '12 grad, although our friendship grew while we worked at Microsoft in Seattle upon graduation. He's always good for lively discussions on anything from tech to politics to sports, all of which were covered over some Cambodia beer after a refreshing dip in the river.

Caleb shares my entrepreneurial passion, constantly working on side projects, often juggling multiple concurrently. He showed me his group messaging app, Minecraft mod, and tank-based infinite runner game. I reciprocated by showing him the half done projects I've built during this trip. We discussed the difficulty of actually completing projects, the last 10% always taking 90% of the work. Even though we both know we should just release a project to get it out there and garner feedback, when push comes to shove, it's difficult to be comfortable enough to release something you know isn't quite good enough just yet.

I've met a number of people online, most of which I've never seen in person. Some were introduced through Firebase, providing support for their side project or company. Others, I devoured their work until deciding to reach out with praise or a request for advice. And vice versa. Living in San Francisco even gave me the opportunity to meet some in the flesh. We consume so much content online and sometimes Internet strangers feel akin to celebrities. But they're just normal people, and a simple email can form a new friendship and possibly turn around that person's day or week.

It took about half an hour for Caleb and I to accept the fact our scheduled transportation for our guided tour through [Bokor National Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Preah_Monivong_National_Park) was never going to show up. Our guesthouse helped book us a private car instead and we enjoyed the day seeing the lush mountainous park at our own pace, stopping by many crumbling buildings of abandoned French outposts, a waterfall strangely adorned for a photo shoot, and some sweeping views of the Cambodian coastline. It wasn't exactly what we had planned, but it's amazing how well a map and Wikipedia can replace a tour guide.

Sadly, Caleb’s visit is over after just one week. He’s headed back to the States, smashing together a variety of vacations and holiday plans before starting an exciting new job at Unity in 2018. We parted ways after shooting the shit over one last game of cards and paying our hilariously low bill given the amount we ate and drank at our riverside accommodations in Kampot. He left for his flight from Phnom Penh and I grabbed a bus to [Koh Rong Sanloem](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Koh_Rong_Sanloem), trading the muddy river banks of the Mekong for the white sand beaches of the Cambodian islands.

The beauty of Saracen Bay on Koh Rong Sanloem lies not in its long white sand beach — which is beautiful, albeit filled with more trash than I imagined — but rather in its simplicity. The bay is free of motorized vehicles and roads, such a rarity in today’s world. Hell, [even the Moon has vehicles on it](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lunar_Roving_Vehicle)! The path from one resort to the next is the beach itself, providing ample opportunity for relaxation in tree swings and hammocks along the way. The beach also served as my seating area for a delicious candlelight BBQ dinner I enjoyed under the stars.

A spark flashes as I snap my fingers, a lighter barely failing to ignite. I stare at my outstretched, upturned palm, dancing flames tricking me into thinking I'm about to summon a magic spell. It’s pitch black out, but my body becomes faintly visible as I continue to tread water, countless [bioluminescent plankton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phytoplankton) revealing themselves upon contact. I'm just a short kayak trip under the stars from Sunset Beach, an isolated spot 30 minutes across the jungle from Saracen Bay. An overhead conversation between strangers an hour ago has left me here, taking in the otherworldliness of this natural wonder.

Last night's sleep was one of the trip's worst, despite my accommodations possibly being the coolest. My "room" at [Sleeping Trees](http://www.sleeping-trees.com/what.html) was a hanging tent suspended just five meters from the crashing waves of Sunset Beach. But a cold brewing all day combined with this trip's second case of food poisoning made for a long and painful night under the stars. I felt barely better in the morning as I boarded a boat to navigate the choppy waters to M’pai Bay on the island's northern coast. But thankfully I made it without losing whatever was left in my stomach.

An article called ["Google Maps' Moat"](https://www.justinobeirne.com/google-maps-moat) piqued my interest as both a technologist and aspiring cartographer. It analyzes Google Maps' introduction of features using second-order data itself built upon other primary data sources, and how Google is uniquely positioned to do this. People underestimate the specificity and accuracy of conclusions drawn from seemingly trivial data. Google does this with satellite and street images. What can they do with my collective search, browser, email, and location histories? Build features to improve my life? Serve me more targeted ads? Data is power and Google has a hell of a lot of it.

Done exploring the beaches of Koh Rong Sanloem, I relocated to [Koh Rong](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Koh_Rong), its confusingly named big brother. It's Cambodia's party island, but I’m in no partying mood. Maybe it’s the duration of this trip so far or maybe it's the upcoming holidays away from family or maybe it’s just me after a few productive days wanting to maintain momentum, but I seek isolation. So I traded the bustling Koh Toch village for [a remote tent village on Coconut Beach](http://www.coconutbeachbungalows.com/). Not as charming as [the tent I threw up in last week](https://jwn.gr/microblog/2017-12-19), but it has the solitude I currently desire.

I’ve been a longtime fan of [Cards Against Humanity](https://cardsagainsthumanity.com/). Actually, I should clarify. I somewhat dislike playing the game. What I admire is the company itself. It's relentlessly opinionated, willing to forego profits and buck trends in favor of their quirky ethos. And they do it with such creativity, from [selling literally nothing](https://www.recode.net/2015/11/28/11620980/cards-against-humanity-sells-nothing-for-71000-on-black-friday) to [mailing people poop](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=57y1Ryr66cM) to [crowdfunding a hole](https://www.polygon.com/2016/11/25/13748292/cards-against-humanity-holiday-hole) to [fake pivoting into a chips company called Prongles](https://www.underconsideration.com/brandnew/archives/new_name_logo_and_packaging_for_prongles_previously_cards_against_humanity_by_45_irving.php). Their recent [CAH Saves America](https://www.cardsagainsthumanitysavesamerica.com/) campaign is equally brilliant, offering poignant social commentary on [wealth inequality](https://cardsagainsthumanityredistributesyourwealth.com/) and [Americas' political and social polarization](https://thepulseofthenation.com/). They're unabashedly brazen, a rarity in today's world.

I joined a snorkeling boat for a morning swim before getting dumped at Koh Toch Village. I stayed in the island's main hub only long enough to eat a truly awful chicken caesar salad for lunch, a poor meal choice on a Cambodian island. A forty-five-minute hike along beaches and through the jungle brought me to Long Set Beach, also referred to as 4 km Beach given its impressive length. Only a handful of resorts dot the beach, a perfect environment for lounging in a beach chair, bumping up my laptop screen's brightness to see it over the bright sun.

Wind has caused problems for boat schedules since I arrived on the islands. The waters between the Cambodian coast and these islands is always choppy, so when the wind picks up, it brings some major swells and cancellations. To avoid getting stuck on the islands beyond my planned departure, I returned to the mainland this morning. Sihanoukville is one of those tourist cities you hate because it's too touristy, so I again ventured away from the crowds to Otres Beach. The expected storm did come, but by that time, I was able to simply enjoy the beautiful sunset it created.

This is the first Christmas I’ve ever spent alone, free of familiar faces. Although the loneliness I feel today is not drastically different than what I've experienced many times during this trip, I feel it much more acutely today simply because it's December 25th. I heavily debated coming home for the holidays but eventually decided against it given the distance and cost and knowing that I wanted to continue traveling. But it feels like Christmas just passed right over me this year. It's another reminder that sometimes I don't appreciate what something means to me until it's already too late.

I woke up to three heavily armed security guards standing over me, asking to see my passport. I can't really blame them. I'd also be curious why a man looking like a cross between the title characters of [*Where the Wild Things Are*](https://images-na.ssl-images-amazon.comimages/microblog/posts/M/MV5BNzQ1NzAwODEwM15BMl5BanBnXkFtZTcwNTE4MjI4Mg@@._V1_SY1000_CR0,0,676,1000_AL_.jpg) and [a puppet from the carnival cat rack game](https://s-media-cache-ak0.pinimg.com/originals/58/e9/6c/58e96c880792dc85846e4066c5bfb1a0.jpg) was fast asleep on the floor. I explained to them how I flew into Singapore from Phnom Penh and was resting during an overnight layover before my morning flight. My story sold well enough and I fell back asleep quickly, knowing I still had a long day ahead.

Jonny, a former Firebase co-worker and close friend from San Francisco, has joined along on my travels, our first destination being Ubud, Indonesia on the island of Bali. It seems Jonny's primary motive is making up for my cheap backpacker living these past three months. We're sharing a bamboo bungalow at [Bali Bohemia](https://www.balibohemia.com/), a hotel adjacent to the courageous and unrestrained inhabitants of [Ubud's Monkey Forest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ubud_Monkey_Forest). We also partook in some fine dining with an eight-course prix fixe tasting menu at [Mozaic](https://mozaic-bali.com/home/). If Jonny had been my travel partner these entire past eight months, my savings might already be depleted.

[Mepantigan](http://www.mepantiganbali.com/about-mepantigan/) is a traditional Balinese martial art and sport taking place in muddy rice paddies. A Christmas gift from my brother and sister-in-law gave Jonny and I a chance to try it ourselves. Our session began with learning their traditional warrior dance, with similar amounts of yelling and chest pounding to New Zealand's [haka](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haka). Covered in body paint, we headed to the mud pits where I promptly took an awkward fall and wrecked my left ankle. Jonny continued on, learning hand-to-hand combat techniques and hilariously having Bob the duck poop on his head. An awesome experience with an unfortunate injury.

Traffic in Bali is an absolute nightmare, especially during the current busy season. I can barely imagine how much worse it would be if travelers weren’t scared off this year by [Mount Agung's ongoing volcanic activity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2017_eruption_of_Mount_Agung) on the island's east side. We sat in plenty of traffic today as we had a private driver take us around greater Ubud. The tour was highlighted by the stunning [Tegallalang rice terraces](http://www.bali-indonesia.com/ubud/tegallalang-rice-terraces.htm) and scenic lunchtime views of [Mount Batur](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mount_Batur), the island's other active volcano. Locals like our driver brush off the volcanoes as just a part of normal life, albeit a dangerous one.

The suckling pig waiting for us at [Ibu Oka](https://www.zomato.com/bali/babi-guling-ibu-oka-ubud/menu) was well worth the walk on a swollen, bruised ankle. Following lunch, we left behind the [moss-covered stone buildings of Ubud](https://www.google.com.sg/search?rlz=1C5CHFA_enUS735US735&biw=1440&bih=803&tbm=isch&sa=1&ei=Tu5OWvj6F8OHggfSooHADg&q=moss+covered+buildings+ubud&oq=moss+covered+buildings+ubud&gs_l=psy-ab.3...8788.9681.0.9867.10.6.0.0.0.0.403.403.4-1.1.0....0...1c.1.64.psy-ab..10.0.0....0.yp9dd--CFK0) for the beaches and bars of Kuta. Honestly, I had low expectations for it given its notoriously trashy reputation. Trashy with regards to physical waste as well as the stereotypical visitors to the area. My fears were confirmed after seeing the piles of plastic and absurd crowds on the main beach. I realized it was a disservice to [call the Cambodian islands dirty](https://jwn.gr/microblog/2017-12-17), as this beach was truly next level.

New Year’s Eve may be my least favorite day of the year. Overhyped, anticlimactic, and a stupid reason to overpay for bottle service and the social status of standing behind a VIP velvet rope. Nevertheless, we aren't in Bali often, so we bought tickets for a party at [Cocoon Beach Club](https://cocoon-beach.com/) in Seminyak. The venue was packed, its pool overflowing with swimsuit-clad partygoers. I did my best to dance in the new year without injuring my ankle further and did pretty well until a girl puked all over my shoes shortly after midnight. Hopefully that event doesn't foreshadow my 2018.

I didn’t expect to be at this point by the time 2018 rolled around. I certainly had no expectations I'd still be traveling, assuming my trip would only last three to six months. I also figured I'd know what was next for my life by this point, but my mind has a tendency to postpone that topic. In 2016, [I ran 850 miles](https://running-2016.firebaseapp.com/). In 2017, [I documented my daily experiences traveling the world](https://jwn.gr/microblog). I don’t know what 2018 has in store yet, but I hope it involves creating the things I’ve had only in my head for far too long.

On today's fast boat to Gili Trawangan, the largest of Indonesia's gorgeous [Gili Islands](https://wikitravel.org/en/Gili_Islands), I read about ["third places,"](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Third_place) social surroundings beyond the usual home ("first place") and work ("second place"). In San Francisco, my "third place" was my coed soccer league for a time and maybe even Golden Gate Park during my year of running. While I've been traveling, I lost not only my "third places," but also my "first" and "second" ones, making me somewhat cede my sense of place in general. Wherever I end up next, I plan to more consciously seek out a healthy "third place."

With Jonny dealing with a case of "Bali Belly" and me coming down with a cold on top of my already sore ankle, we spent much of the day poolside at our resort, the [Pearl of Trawangan](https://www.pearloftrawangan.com/). After hours of swimming, reading, and some competitive games of [Würfel Bohnanza](https://boardgamegeek.com/boardgame/111148/wurfel-bohnanza), we walked the dirt road spanning the eastern side of Gili T in search of dinner. We ended up at a pop-up beachside movie theater for a showing of the surprisingly humorous [“The Nice Guys”](http://www.imdb.com/title/tt3799694/) before closing out the night with some live reggae music. A relaxing day in paradise.

There's awe and trepidation aplenty when diving alongside turtles the size of satellite dishes and [moray eels reminiscent of Mario's adventures](https://www.mariowiki.com/Maw-Ray). I've had many remarkable experiences like this over the past eight months, but what I really desire is that sudden revelation, that moment of pure clarity about my future. I naively assumed it would happen at some point on this journey, but my life isn't a movie and I won't always be lucky enough for nature to reveal its mysteries to me. In the meantime, I'll keep pushing forward into the abyss, taking in its beauty along the way.

Traveling with someone puts your friendship in a unique situation. I'm not used to spending 24/7 with the same person, not even roommates. But when traveling, I typically eat every meal with my travel companion and each activity is a shared one. As much as I enjoy spending time with Jonny (and the others I've traveled with, for that matter), sometimes I need to step away for some alone time. Despite Jonny making an art out of pushing my buttons for his enjoyment at points today, our final meal on Gili T reminded me how much I appreciate his friendship.

Podcasts have replaced my consumption of TV shows and movies while traveling. I just finished season two of ["Heavyweight,"](https://gimletmedia.com/heavyweight/) a curiosity amongst podcasts in which Jonathan Goldstein uses dry humor to narrate the seemingly trivial redemption of everyday people. He bluntly addresses our tendency to spend our lives holding guilt or regretting things which can be resolved with a single, uncomfortable conversation. Humans are prideful, afraid to openly express our true feelings for a myriad of reasons. If there's one lesson to take from the show, it's that you'll regret things you don't say much more than things you do.

Nusa Dua, my last stop with Jonny as well as my last one in Indonesia, is an area on the southern tip of Bali known for its many ritzy beachside resorts. Ours is [Inaya Putri Bali](http://inayaputribali.com/), a gorgeous complex with several restaurants, easy beach access, an impressive multi-level infinity pool, and extravagant golf cart delivery of your luggage and your person a whole 50 meters from the reception area to your room. It stands in stark contrast to our recent adventures in Kuta, and it's a perfect place for us to end our travels together on a relaxing note.

Jonny and I said our goodbyes as I headed to the airport for a flight to Chiang Mai, Thailand, returning to the country to hit the northern part I missed on my last visit. I’ve been looking forward to seeing Chiang Mai, a major hub for "digital nomads" like myself given its cheap cost of living and preponderance of coffee shops and co-working spaces with strong Wi-Fi. After weeks of splurging on the beaches of Cambodia and Indonesia which in many ways felt like a mini-vacation within this larger trip, it’s back to hostel living and street food for me.

I had one of the best breakfasts of the trip this morning at [Rustic & Blue](http://rusticandblue.com/), where I met up with Tracy, a friend of a Firebaser who currently lives and works in Chiang Mai. She took me to the co-working space she works out of in the old city, where I did my best not to get distracted by the ongoing college football championship game. I took off in the early afternoon to explore the old city, a 1.5 km by 1.5 km square area surrounded by a moat and unsurprisingly jam-packed with markets, temples, and delicious food.

I finally managed to see *Star Wars: Episode VIII — The Last Jedi* this afternoon, an entertaining and unexpectedly thought-provoking follow-up to what I consider a disappointingly mediocre *Episode VII*. But the most surprising part of the experience actually occurred before the film's iconic text scrolling over a starscape even began. Following the previews, the screen prompted the audience to stand for a two-minute-long musical homage to [the late Thai King Bhumibol](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhumibol_Adulyadej). I couldn't help but shake my head at the thought of being forced to stand in a theater back home, a giant red MAGA hat projected on the screen.

Visiting elephants treated humanely is surprisingly difficult. There are obvious places to avoid, including those offering basket rides, a dangerous activity for which an elephant is not well suited. Beyond that, each agency claims moral high ground over the others. They name themselves with buzzwords like "sanctuary" to project humane practices, all the while mistreating elephants once the day's visitors depart. The gentle majesty of the elephants which naturally makes me smile stands in stark contrast to the brutal, profitable business surrounding them. Despite my best attempts at responsible tourism, I’m left unsure of my role in the whole thing.

Today started as many good days do — with a delicious meal. [Khao soi](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Khao_soi) is a spicy, Burmese-influenced soup-like dish containing both deep-fried and boiled egg noodles that is a specialty of northern Thailand. A meager 40 baht ($1.25) was enough for a filling bowl of the stuff at the popular [Mae Sai](https://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/Restaurant_Review-g293917-d7779592-Reviews-Khao_Soi_Mae_Sai-Chiang_Mai.html) restaurant. Following the meal — and a fruit smoothie stop — Tracy, her college friend Steven, and I jumped in a van headed for Pai. I immediately knew I liked the small, peaceful town nestled along a river in a valley amongst the mountains of northern Thailand.

I can’t help but think that Pai feels artificial, although not in an entirely negative way. It's overflowing with westerners who come for the laid-back atmosphere, beautiful riverside lodgings, and daily night market which consumes the town's main streets and features an impressive variety of Thai and western staples. But it feels like it's losing its charm, a place transitioning into a tourist trap. As with other places I've visited along this trip, tourism has transformed it, providing much needed jobs and money for locals while simultaneously papering over some things which made it worth visiting in the first place.

I had high standards for [Tham Lod Cave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tham_Lot_cave) after some [remarkable caving experiences in Phong Nha, Vietnam](https://jwn.gr/microblog/locations/phong-nha) Thankfully, today's visit was worth the trip. Our non-English speaking guide used grunts and her forefinger to point out rock formations resembling an alligator, a UFO, and randomly even a breast as we explored the enormous cave. But the tour highlight was climbing aboard a rickety bamboo raft to wade through the cave's shallow waters teeming with thousands of massive half-meter-long fish as bats screeched loudly in the darkness above. I'm always amazed at the diversity of life in such seemingly inhospitable environments.
