As I gazed upon the mountains from [an egg-shaped swinging chair](https://www.facebook.com/pg/iloveupaicafe/posts/), a thought struck: maybe [my post about avoiding comfort](https://jwn.gr/microblog/2017-11-17) is actually about subconsciously recognizing diminishing returns. Comfort could just be a symptom. I've recently grown weary of travel, possibly because it's become easier and I see my personal growth plateauing as a result. Maybe I leave things once I get out of them most of what I think I can get. This line of thought may be as naive as my last and may even indicate a personality flaw. Or just maybe I'm inching closer to some underlying truth.

Although I could easily continue eating my way through Pai's night market, it was time to move on. An early rise and a seven-hour van ride brought me to Chiang Rai, famous for the pristinely haunting [Wat Rong Khun ("White Temple")](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wat_Rong_Khun). The city itself lacks Pai's charm and Chiang Rai's scale, often used as the last stopover before Laos. A girl on my van was actually en route to Laos for the Gibbon Experience. I dispensed travel knowledge from [my time there](https://jwn.gr/microblog/locations/huay-xai), surprising even myself at how much I knew about a country I could barely locate months ago.

As I assemble the past week's ramblings into a coherent newsletter each Wednesday, apprehension builds out of a desire for it to consistently display depth and creativity. I often agonize over whether this week’s edition is too bland or uninspired. So I throw in [a stream of consciousness](https://jwn.gr/microblog/2017-06-23) here and [a rap](https://jwn.gr/microblog/2017-11-29) there in the midst of standard posts recapping my days. But sometimes inspiration or motivation are lacking. I need to remind myself that not every post will be my best and, by definition, half of them will be below average. Then I write, hit publish, and carry on.

I spent most of today going through [YearCompass’ Year Ahead Worksheet](http://yearcompass.com/). It was an opportunity to look back on an eventful and tumultuous 2017 and look forward to a fulfilling and productive 2018. Given my tendency to be constantly in motion, I sometimes feel precariously on edge, like a spinning top that may topple over at any moment. I rarely take time, let alone an entire day, to stop, turn my attention inward, and reflect on the status of my life. Today didn’t exactly change anything, but it was enlightening to see what in my life I truly care about.

My Fitbit got run over by a car today, which isn't a thing that typically happens to watches. I’m a happy Fitbit customer, although the rubber straps consistently bubble and need free replacement. The latest [Charge 2](https://www.fitbit.com/charge2) has straps which still bubble, but are detachable, surely reducing replacement costs. But now the connectors break. Nothing that can't be fixed with tape, right? Wrong. Tape failing at an inoportune time led to today's car incident. The watch is still salvaeable, but there's a moral here: solve the root problem or be forced to deal with new problems caused by your workaround.

I’m back in Chiang Mai after a few quiet, productive days spent hopping around temples and coffee shops in Chiang Rai. I spent most of my time there on my computer, riding that zen programming flow which has been all too rare this past year. It’s amazing how much I can get done when my mind is clear and I just need to churn out code. If this microblog were film, the past few entries would be a single shot zooming in on me hunched over my computer, the sun and moon rising and setting in rapid succession behind me.

I recently started following [Naval Ravikant](https://twitter.com/naval), the founder of AngelList, on Twitter. He's a sharp follow, uniquely blending together interests in startups, crypto, and philosophy. [He got on Periscope today](https://www.pscp.tv/w/1eaKbqrWloRxX) and, although I'm not a huge fan of the format, the hour he spent answering live questions was exceptionally insightful. One of the many bits of wisdom he imparted involved the vast disparity between how long people stay in jobs and how little time they spend applying for or considering them. As someone doing a lot of career soul-searching, it settled some concerns about my indecision as of late.

Being twelve to fifteen hours ahead of friends and family back home has made staying in touch difficult. It can be frustrating when a simple back and forth takes place across an entire day given opposite sleep schedules. That's why it's been comforting to be somewhere without many plans but with a connection like Tracy who shares many of my interests. Between a memorable [kathoey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kathoey) cabaret show last night and our conversations about love, life, and everything in between tonight over some traditional Thai [hot pot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hot_pot), we've become quick friends and she's helped make the road feel less lonely.

After slightly over four months in Southeast Asia, my time here has drawn to a close. I look forward to one day revisiting the wonderful and vibrant East as it still has plenty more to offer. But for now, my worldwide trip enters the home stretch, a thirty-hour journey taking me back to Europe for one final stop before returning to the USA. Any anxieties about my future are overpowered by my desire to finish this trip strong, to squeeze every last drop out of this experience and carry that momentum into whatever I do and wherever I go next.

I find myself back in the charming city of Porto, one of my favorite places along this entire journey. Its scenic riverside setting and delicious wines surely deserve some credit, but, as longtime readers of the microblog know, [the location itself doesn’t tell the whole story](https://jwn.gr/microblog/2017-06-25). I had a wonderful [chance encounter with an Italian named Germana](https://jwn.gr/microblog/2017-05-28) here on my first visit, leading me to [return for a long weekend](https://jwn.gr/microblog/locations/porto-2) to see her again. My third stay in Portugal is the last international stop of my trip, and it feels like a fitting way to close this thing out.

Today will most likely be my lifetime high-water mark for the amount of hair on my head and face. With the worldwide trip soon coming to an end and my desire to look like my regular self once again, I spent a transformative hour at [Barbearia Porto](https://www.facebook.com/barbeariaporto1946/) losing what felt like two pounds of weight and five years of age. I now do a double take when looking at the unfamiliar face in the mirror, retraining my mind which acclimated to my shaggy *Into The Wild* look. It feels good to be back, and to no longer need a comb.

There really are few date formats better than a surprise date. The anticipation of the unknown, the sheer cluelessness over what to even wear, the fear on the other person's face when I hint that I may be taking them skydiving. I'm a real sucker for surprise dates, whether I'm the one planning them or just tagging along. Germana and I split duties today, her organizing a relaxing afternoon couples massage for us at a spa and me following that up with a meat-filled dinner at [Terminal 4450](http://terminal4450.pt/). Today was further evidence that surprise dates are the best dates.

Germana and I hopped on the train this morning for a day trip to [Braga](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Braga), a quaint city an hour north of Porto. The highlight was most certainly the sanctuary of [*Bom Jesus do Monte*](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bom_Jesus_do_Monte) ("Good Jesus of the Mount"). Moss-covered chapels depicting life-sized Stations of the Cross lined its lower staircase. Its main upper staircase featured sculptures and fountains dedicated to the five senses, zigzagging up to a Baroque church containing a detailed altar scene of Jesus' crucifixion. History and meaning permeated the grounds, making the sanctuary feel like a plot point straight out of a Dan Brown novel.

It's common for me to assume technological solutions exist for every problem. As soon as issues arise in my life, I start brainstorming ways to solve them using the vast arsenal of apps, websites, and programming languages at my disposal. But some things are immune to such weapons. Want to solve homelessness in San Francisco? Or reduce political polarization? Or figure out how to make things work with the pretty girl who lives on the opposite side of the world? Unfortunately, technology probably won't help me out there. My personal classifier hasn't been trained on how to solve such things.

I don’t have much experience leading a typical daily life in a foreign country outside of a short summer abroad in Spain during college. I'm testing it out while in Porto, but it's taking time to get comfortable. Even simple things like grocery shopping are painful. Staples from back home bear unknown brands or are nonexistent. Translating Portuguese words into English and metric units into imperial doubles shopping time. The tomato paste I used as a chili base was too sweet, tasting almost like ketchup. Differences in culture and lifestyle seem more plentiful than when I was quickly traveling along.

While Germana has been going off to work during the days, I've headed into Porto's old town in search of cafes out of which to do my own work. After she finished up this afternoon, we meandered to [Ponte d’Arrábida](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arr%C3%A1bida_Bridge), a bridge across the Douro River which was the largest concrete arch in the world upon its completion in 1963. It's home to [Porto Bridge Climb](https://www.portobridgeclimb.com/home-en), a 262-step ascent which took us 65 meters above the water. We chose the perfect time to go, catching the sun as it set into the Atlantic Ocean, painting the sky pink and orange.

["Call Me By Your Name"](http://www.imdb.com/title/tt5726616/) is a touching love story, albeit one whose dialogue at times requires a film degree to appreciate. The most personally impactful scene comes near the end, in which the main character's father contemplates how failed relationships change us: "We rip out so much of ourselves to be cured of things faster than we should that we go bankrupt by the age of 30 and have less to offer each time we start with someone new. But to make yourself feel nothing so as not to feel anything — what a waste!" Sometimes words hit me hard.

Germana and I made quick work of season four of [*Black Mirror*](http://www.imdb.com/title/tt2085059/), my favorite in the surprisingly crowded genre of dystopian TV series. Although this season felt somewhat less fresh than prior ones, it once again expertly threaded the needle to create plots which felt just a few years — and a couple technological advances — away. My personal favorites were the Star Trek parody-turned-tragedy ["USS Callister"](http://www.imdb.com/title/tt5710974/) and the hauntingly nihilistic ["Crocodile"](http://www.imdb.com/title/tt5710976/) which repeatedly left me breathless. *Black Mirror* is, in my opinion, required viewing for anyone building the technologies of tomorrow so as to ensure these stories remain as fiction.

Portugal may be the last international stop on my trip, but that doesn’t mean I'm done city-hopping. After Germana finished up work for the day, we took a bus to Lisbon for a reunion with a handful of international friends I made during my time in San Francisco. It was my [second time](https://jwn.gr/microblog/locations/milan) seeing Mythila, my former roommate, and her husband, Edoardo, on this trip and my first seeing Julio and Victoria, both of whom now live in Paris. We started the trip by catching up with each other while sharing laughs, stories, and copious amounts of fried Portuguese tapas.

After many months of scheduling daily activities for myself, it was relieving to hand over the reigns to Edoardo for the day. He and Mythila are quite the foodies, so the six of us spent much of the day traveling from one dining establishment to the next. And that was totally fine with me, as I enjoyed every stop on the epic food tour, from my glorious, sugar-filled return to [Pop Cereal Cafe](https://jwn.gr/microblog/2017-06-02) to the striking waterside views at [Ponto Final](https://get10things.com/lisbon/dinner-lisbon/ponto-final/) to [Pastéis de Belém](http://pasteisdebelem.pt/en/)'s warm gooey pastel de nata to the unique flavors in the dishes at [Lost In](http://www.lostinesplanada.com/#).

I woke up today feeling tired. Tired of sightseeing. Tired of constantly being on planes, trains, and buses. Tired of waking up in unfamiliar places. Tired of having no routine. I'm very much looking forward to being in one place for a while and not worrying about how to get to my next destination. It felt a bit like I was running on autopilot today, a shame given I was surrounded by friends I now rarely see. But upon returning to Porto and getting in bed, I was happy to have one less day of sightseeing and travel remaining.

I’ve struggled in the past with not saying things until it was too late. Although I'm mainly talking about romantic relationships, similar issues have arisen with friendships and at work. I'm usually one to speak my mind, but I clam up when it concerns things which can fundamentally change the course of the relationship, fearing the worst. But it's a terrible life strategy. The conversation eventually happens anyway and, by that time, I'm full of pent-up resentment which blinds me from any objectivity. I'm exasperated from committing this mistake time and again. It's time to stop avoiding these difficult discussions.

"Everything's relative" is one of those trite phrases I believe people rarely actually think about. So, naturally, I've given it considerable thought. Should the fact people are suffering from poverty or living under autocratic regimes make my daily pains and disappointments any less painful and disappointing? I think not, since I'm allowed to feel an emotion even if another person has reason to feel that emotion more strongly. Nonetheless, maintaining perspective is important. There are different degrees of pain and suffering, whole classes of which I've avoided by sheer luck. Everything may be relative, but it's critical to realize that.

Daily life often feels like a constant fight to get rid of the sense of uncertainty, an intolerance for the unknown. That drive for security and simplicity is, ironically, often the root cause of my insecurity and feelings of being overwhelmed. Rarely can I just exist in the current moment, embracing an indeterminate future. But that's exactly what I attempted to do today on my last full day abroad. The comforts of home were a tempting siren song urging me to look beyond the present, but as my time with Germana wound down, I fought the urge to glimpse ahead.

You'd think a grown-ass adult would realize there are infinitely more appropriate times to clip your fingernails than on a crowded transatlantic flight. But you'd be wrong, as I discovered on today's flight back to America. Thankfully, this trip hardened me against unsanitary behaviors and I eventually landed in Newark, taking public transit onto New York City. It's my first visit to Brooklyn, where I'm staying with Matt, a friend working alongside me on Communities Rising, and his wife, Archana. Despite the sticker shock from consuming [an albeit delicious $27 burger](https://www.pizzalovesemily.com/), it feels good to be back in my homeland.

Despite bone-chilling temperatures to which the West Coast has made me soft, I meandered through downtown Brooklyn, along the Brooklyn Heights Promenade, over the Brooklyn Bridge, right alongside One World Trade Center. The 9/11 Museum drew me in, a moving, exceptionally well put together remembrance of lives lost and heroes formed on that tragic day. It's dizzying to contemplate 9/11's compounding effects, from the formation of absurd airplane regulations to the growing wave of nationalism spreading throughout the West brought on by our ongoing fight against terrorism. I didn't realize at the time how that day would really change everything.

Each Saturday, Matt attends classes as part of Columbia University's MBA program. I joined him and many of his fellow classmates after today's classes for a night full of food, drinks, and engaging conversations. Following so many months on the road traveling as a vagabond, it was strange to be back surrounded by a group of people so focused on their careers. I saw that career-oriented version of myself in nearly everyone I talked to. But, as I enter this next stage of my career, I cannot help but see it in a new light and with a fresh perspective.

Despite a late last night, I was wide awake by 6 AM, well before an alarm scheduled to wake me for my train to Harrisburg, Pennsylvania. As I laid motionless on the inflatable mattress, staring at a blank ceiling, I mulled over whether it was jet lag or the emotional cocktail of excitement and anxiety about my worldwide trip ending which roused me. After all the planes, trains, boats, buses, vans, cars, motorbikes, tuk tuks, songthaews, bicycles, kayaks, and [water buffalo](https://jwn.gr/microblog/2017-10-25) I used as transportation over the past nine months, today’s train ride was bringing me to my final destination.

Time to grade performance on my trip goals. (1) [Maintain this microblog](https://jwn.gr/microblog/2017-05-24): A. Despite some delayed newsletters, every day was documented. (2) [Walk 14,286 steps daily](https://jwn.gr/microblog/2017-05-25): A-. Aggressive goal accomplished 80% of days, easily averaging above target. (3) [Meditate daily](https://jwn.gr/microblog/2017-05-26): F. I cannot recall the last time I opened Headspace. (4) [Meet someone new daily](https://jwn.gr/microblog/2017-05-28): B-. I put myself out there frequently, although I became reclusive these past couple months. (5) [Brainstorm ideas daily](https://jwn.gr/microblog/2017-05-29): F. Would grade myself lower if I could. (6) [Release something every week](https://jwn.gr/microblog/2017-05-30): D. Overly optimistic given working while traveling proved difficult, but several projects progressed.

A malaise slowly but thoroughly blanketed me two years ago. Frustration with work, dismay over American politics, doubts concerning my romantic relationship. They eventually drove me to quit my job, stuff my belongings into a storage unit, and book a one way ticket far away. Standing here, on the other side of that nine month journey, I don a new outlook forged from coming to terms with my shortcomings and contemplating what truly matters to me. I can’t change the past, but I can — and I sure as hell will — make sure I don’t repeat those same mistakes again.
